title: How To Eat Healthy On The Go
summary: You never know what you'll find to eat once you’re out in the world. Having your own food can help you avoid overspending or consuming food that isn’t healthy for you. Eating local cuisine will help you appreciate the culture or area you're in and it will also help to avoid eating unhealthy fast food. If you have a long road trip ahead of you, you can always pack some nuts or trail mix in your bag. You can also always take a bag of carrots with you on the plane to munch on once in the air.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Going on a road trip, catching an early morning flight or going to your new internship for the first time can all be stressful. You have to leave home at ungodly hours to get there on time, you have to read through pages of instructions and you might even have to fend for yourself without your parents\u2019 help. This is where packing healthy snacks comes in handy.
On-the-go food isn\u2019t always healthy and nutritious. With more fast food chains popping up everywhere, it\u2019s becoming increasingly difficult for us to find healthy meals that are also quick and convenient to eat. If you find yourself caught off guard by these circumstances often, here are some tips on how you can eat healthy while traveling or commuting.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Pack your own food"),mdx("p",null,"You never know what you\u2019ll find to eat once you\u2019re out in the world. Sometimes, you run into places that don\u2019t even serve food, let alone healthy snacks. Other times, you run into places where the food isn\u2019t healthy. If you have a lot of traveling to do, or you have an early morning flight to catch, it\u2019s a good idea to pack some food for the trip. You can make a quick stop at the grocery store for some fruit and vegetables or you can pick up some protein bars or nuts at the airport or on your way to the airport."),mdx("p",null,"You should also keep a water bottle in your bag or in your car so that you\u2019re always prepared. Having your own food can help you avoid overspending or consuming food that isn\u2019t healthy for you. While you may be able to find some healthy snacks at the airport, it\u2019s likely that they\u2019re fairly expensive."),mdx("h2",null,"Try out local cuisine"),mdx("p",null,"While you should still pack your own food, you should also try to eat some local cuisine while you\u2019re traveling. This will help you appreciate the culture or area you\u2019re in and it will also help you avoid eating unhealthy fast food. You should always travel with an open mind and try new things. This isn\u2019t just true for traveling; it\u2019s also true for eating."),mdx("p",null,"If you\u2019re staying with a host family while abroad, ask them what they usually eat. If you\u2019re staying in a hotel, look up the best restaurants in the area. You may even want to ask your new friends where they like to go. If you\u2019re going abroad to study or work, ask your classmates or coworkers where they like to go."),mdx("h2",null,"Eat protein-rich meals"),mdx("p",null,`Protein is a must-have in any healthy diet. It\u2019s great for your muscles, bones and skin and it\u2019s also good for your digestive system. Protein is found in fish, beans, nuts, eggs, milk and yogurt. You can pair these with some healthy carbs to create a balanced meal.
If you have a long road trip ahead of you, you can always pack some nuts or trail mix in your bag. If you have an early morning flight, you can grab an egg or yogurt wrap or get a milk or yogurt smoothie to go. You can also always take a bag of carrots with you on the plane to munch on once in the air.`),mdx("h2",null,"Choose whole wheat bread and crackers"),mdx("p",null,`You can always ask for a side of whole wheat bread at a restaurant, but it\u2019s always better to bring your own. You can also pick up a couple of whole wheat crackers at the airport before you board your flight. If you\u2019re flying with a friend, you can always share.
If you\u2019re staying at a friend\u2019s place or at a hotel, you can always ask the kitchen staff at the hotel if they have any whole wheat bread or crackers. If they don\u2019t, you can always pick up some at the grocery store.`),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t forget the veggies and fruits"),mdx("p",null,`Veggies and fruits are always a healthy choice, no matter what. You can always pick up some carrots or apples at the grocery store before you go or you can ask a friend if they have some in their fridge.
If you\u2019re staying in a hotel, you can always ask the kitchen staff if they have any vegetables or fruits lying around. If not, you can always go to the grocery store and pick some up.`),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"Eating healthy while you\u2019re on the go isn\u2019t an easy task \u2014 especially when you\u2019re not used to it. It takes time and a lot of preparation, and it\u2019s certainly not something that you can do overnight. With these tips, you\u2019ll be able to eat healthy on the go and be prepared for whatever life throws at you."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Get Moving When You Don't Have Time for the Gym

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`New Year, same old resolutions. If you\u2019re anything like the majority of people, chances are that you have made the same resolution to get fitter, healthier and happier this year as you did last year. But with a packed work schedule, social calendar and everything else going on in your life it can be difficult to find time to hit the gym or take up that new Zumba class you signed up for last October but never went to again.
And yet so many of us do manage to get moving. Yes, it might involve setting your alarm an hour earlier than usual, waking up on Saturday morning instead of Friday night and putting in some serious dedication \u2014 but it is possible. So if you\u2019re struggling to find time for the gym here are some creative ways how you can get moving when you don\u2019t have time for the gym:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Best Way to Get Your Kids to Eat Their Vegetables
How to Make Your Kitchen a Healthier Place

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"You probably don\u2019t need anyone to tell you that the modern Western diet is not healthy. Whether in a home, restaurant, cafeteria or any other eatery, almost all food establishments serve high-calorie, high-sugar and high-fat meals that are laden with salt and unhealthy oils.What is unfortunate about this situation is that many people have no choice but to eat this way on a regular basis. If you work in an office, it\u2019s highly likely that your building has its own kitchen where a catered lunch service prepares hot lunches for staff every day. Similarly, if you go to school, there will most likely be a canteen serving the same type of unhealthy food as an adult educational institution.The good news is that even if you are stuck eating these foods on a daily basis, you can make your kitchen a healthier place by altering what goes into the meals you cook at home and the ones that you buy. Here are some tips on how you can do just that:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Healthy Snacks More Exciting
The Benefits of a Healthy Diet - And How It Can Improve Your Mood
Exercising Your Way to a Fitter You: Walk or Run - Which Is Best for You?

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"In today\u2019s fast-paced world, we have less time to work out and still keep up with all our responsibilities. But with the right plan, anyone can make time for exercise. The question is: What type of exercise should you focus on to get the best results in the shortest amount of time? Walking or running may seem like two very different exercises, but when it comes to burning fat and calories, your body responds in similar ways no matter which one you choose. In this article, we\u2019ll discuss the benefits of each one and which is best for you based on your personal fitness level. Keep reading to discover more!"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Ultimate Guide to Understanding - And Improving - Your Metabolism

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Your metabolism is essentially the rate at which your body burns calories and converts them into energy. It\u2019s a process that happens automatically, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and it has a huge impact on how many calories you burn every day and how much weight you could potentially lose if you change your diet to reflect an exercise program. You see, your metabolism is responsible for burning all the fat in your body. Every single calorie you take in from food is first stored as fat somewhere in your body, and then broken down to be used as energy \u2013 the very thing that powers everything you do from breathing to blinking. Metabolism has several components that work together to help maintain it:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Create a Healthy Grocery List on a Budget

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you\u2019re on a tight budget, it can feel like hitting up the grocery store is one of the last things you can afford to do. However, there are ways to make your food dollars go further and still eat well.
Instead of making weekly trips to multiple stores and markets, plan a shopping day and hit one store at a time. Look for sales in that store before you go and stock up on foods that are good value. You might even consider investing in a membership card or becoming an insider or club member so you get vouchers or other discounts. Adding your own spin on some classic cheap meals will also help you save money without sacrificing nutrition. It just takes some planning and research to make it work!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Healthy Eating Easier with Leftovers

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Are you feeling so over-whelmed with the new year and its resolutions that you\u2019ve decided to skip lunch for the foreseeable future? Or perhaps you\u2019re just exhausted by how much effort it seems to take to eat healthy. While eating well isn\u2019t as simple as following a diet \u2014 there are so many different factors that go into it, and we all have our own personal preferences when it comes to what makes a meal healthy. But, there are ways to make eating well a piece of cake. Leftovers are one of those ways!
A meal made from scratch is an excellent way to ensure that you\u2019re staying on track with your New Year\u2019s resolutions. However, cooking every night is not realistic for most people. That doesn\u2019t mean you can\u2019t enjoy home-cooked meals without going through all the stressors of making them yourself \u2013 leftover cooking is your solution!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Ways to Make Your Commute Less Stressful

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you think about your daily commute, it probably doesn\u2019t strike you as being particularly stressful. In fact, many people see their daily drive to work or school as a time for peace and quiet. After all, what could possibly be stressful about getting from point A to point B?
It\u2019s true that your commute isn\u2019t inherently stressful. In theory, it\u2019s just a short period of time each day when you go from home to work (or vise versa). But even the most seemingly insignificant details can make a big difference. Read on to learn more about how you can reduce stress during your commute and get to work happier every day!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
